user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 21.17.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
Yes. UtList_NewNode calls memcpy(AllocNode->Node.Data, Data, DataSize) (and earlier memset(AllocNode,0, sizeof(union))) without validating the pointer/size inputs. This can read/write out of bounds. Example violations: (1) Caller does UtList_Add(&head, &some_uint32, sizeof(uint64_t), tag) — Data points to a 4‑byte object but DataSize==8, so memcpy reads 8 bytes past the source object. (2) Caller passes Data == NULL with DataSize > 0, or malloc returns NULL so AllocNode is NULL — then memset/memcpy are invoked on an invalid pointer. In these cases the use of memcpy/memset can access beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters, violating Rule 21.17.
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified UtList_Add code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/2813.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_Add:
```c
void UtList_Add(UtListHead_t *ListHead, void *Data, uint32 DataSize, uint32 Tag)
{
    UtListNode_t *TagHead;
    UtListNode_t *NewNode;

    TagHead = UtList_GetHead(ListHead, Tag);
    if (TagHead != NULL)
    {
        NewNode      = UtList_NewNode(Data, DataSize);
        NewNode->Tag = Tag;
        UtList_Insert_Before(TagHead, NewNode);
    }
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified UtList_Add code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original UtList_Add with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as UtList_Add.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call UtList_Add to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of UtList_Add as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, UtList_Add will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of UtList_Add as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
